entities.text: Come and join the discussion on long sequence generation of
#LLMs

(10am EDT).  I'll talk about recent work on efficient LLM inference, e.g., H2O, StreamingLLM, Dejavu, from different perspectives: 1) Efficiency: reduce KVCache & weight IOs bottleneck 2) New ability: interesting insights that enables infinite streaming setting.

You'll hear how these three work iteratively inspires each other to produce interesting results üòÜ and a discussion on potential paths towards REAL infinite context modeling.

PS: Very excited to speak at

entities.name: LightOn
entities.text: @LightOnIO
meet up again after 3 years!
arxiv.org/abs/2306.14048
(h2o)
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
(streamingllm)
openreview.net/pdf?id=wIPIhHd‚Ä¶
(dejavu)

Here are the AI news that marked previous week! üß† (brace yourselves it's been a crazy period - I don't say that lightly)

* Super cool paper (congrats

entities.name: Tim Rockt√§schel
entities.text: @_rockt

entities.name: Chrisantha Fernando
entities.text: @chrisantha_f
& team):  "PromptBreeder: Self-Referential Self-Improvement via Prompt Evolution"
arxiv.org/abs/2309.16797

At this point we all know of these clever LLM prompts - "Let's think step by step" being arguably the most famous one.

The thing is such hand-crafted prompts are obviously sub-optimal. In this paper LLMs evolve their own prompts through self-referential self-improvement. Reminds me of

entities.name: Kenneth Stanley
entities.text: @kenneth0stanley

's Picbreeder work (I suppose the paper title was inspired by it :) ).

* 21 year old CS student (

entities.name: Luke Farritor
entities.text: @LukeFarritor
) made a major breakthrough in

entities.name: Nat Friedman
entities.text: @natfriedman

's Vesuvius challenge and won 40.000$: his ML algo read the first word from an unopened Herculaneum scroll! The word is apparently "œÄŒøœÅœÜœÖœÅŒ±œÇ" which means "purple dye" or "cloths of purple".

The scrolls were discovered in 1750s but are in such a state that they can not be opened and we must use ML to figure out what's written on them.

Blog:
scrollprize.org/firstletters

entities.name: Chip Huyen
entities.text: @chipro
's new blog post is out: Multimodality and Large Multimodal Models (LMMs):
huyenchip.com/2023/10/10/mul‚Ä¶
Nice high level overview of the topic! I would just add multilinguality to the LLM research directions :)) (see my project as well:
github.com/gordicaleksa/O‚Ä¶

entities.name: Nathan Benaich
entities.text: @nathanbenaich

just released this year's state of AI report!

Check it out:
stateof.ai

It's probably the best high level resource to figure out what happened over the last year - thus making it perfect for people who are not in the "AI trenches" like myself, but I'm sure I've missed out on important details myself as well :))

* Amazing new paper introducing RingAttention (nice work

entities.name: Hao Liu
entities.text: @haoliuhl

!), enabling scaling context lengths to 0.5M tokens and beyond! Well kind of, depends on device count - more precisely it enables training and inference of sequences that are up to device count times longer than previously possible:
arxiv.org/abs/2310.01889
Related work, introduces StreamingLLMs (allowing for infinite context lengths? I wonder what are the caveats, it's not exact attn mechanism it uses sparse attn pattern):
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453‚Ä¶
* Reading someone's thoughts? Sounds like sci-fi? It's not, check out

entities.name: Tanishq Mathew Abraham, Ph.D.
entities.text: @iScienceLuvr
's new paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2305.18274‚Ä¶

we just had him in my Discord server as well (will try to upload the vid soon!).

* Open source alternative to GPT-4 vision: LLaVA (Large Language and Vision Assistant):
llava-vl.github.io
and related cool paper "Improved baselines with Visual Instruction Tuning" that further improves LLaVA:
arxiv.org/abs/2310.03744
* People are pushing the state of the art by fine-tuning open source LLM base models like recent Mistral 7B model, check out this:
x.com/_lewtun/status‚Ä¶
* Related, Mistral AI has published their paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06825

(9 pages only)

*

entities.name: OpenAI
entities.text: @OpenAI
's DALLE-3 paper is out as well:
cdn.openai.com/papers/DALL_E_‚Ä¶
* Hyped up new paper "Language Models Represent Space and Time":
arxiv.org/abs/2310.02207

. They show they can find an actual wold map inside of Llama 2 activations. There's been a debate on their definition of a "world model" as commonly defined. Just by showing that the model has an internal representation of a world MAP doesn't mean it has the model of the world.

*

entities.name: Replit ‚†ï
entities.text: @Replit
is giving out free access to their AIs! (code completion and code assistance) They'll be burning a ton of GPUs but this might be a great opportunity for beginners to check them out:
blog.replit.com/ai4all

they are a "cloud based IDE" but on steroids if you never heard of them.

* This is big! OpenWebMath, a massive dataset containing every math document found on the internet (14.7B tokens) - with equations in LaTeX format. We've shown that datasets like these improve reasoning of LLMs and datasets contributions are among the most important contributions in the field.

Paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2310.06786

entities.name: Keiran Paster
entities.text: @keirp1

et al)

* "Everything about Distributed Training and Efficient Finetuning" - in depth blog, highly recommend if interested in this topic.
sumanthrh.com/post/distribut‚Ä¶
Phew. :)) Accelerate. ü´°
I know this paper is ~6 months old, but quite intrigued by the attention sinking phenomenon
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
while the idea is now used for streaming LMs, and implemented in many systems, I am curious of the how/why (which probably has consequences for output quality).

This looks legit. Attention heads tend to use the beginning of sequence for "null attention", so maintaining those tokens at the start of the KV cache allows for better sliding-window generation of long text. Can also be combined with long context tricks.
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Figure showing perplexity impact of StreamingLLM compared to dense and windowed attention across 4 different LLMs. From https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

entities.text: Heading to ICLR! I‚Äôm writing fewer papers now to train more Llamas, but proud of our work here: Instruction Backtranslation (
arxiv.org/abs/2308.06259
), Attention Sinks, (
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
) In Context Pretraining (
arxiv.org/abs/2310.10638
) and RA-DIT (
arxiv.org/abs/2310.01352
üöÄOur StreamingLLM (Attention Sink
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
) is now merged into Transformers' main branch:
github.com/huggingface/tr‚Ä¶
. It enables infinite chat with your favorite LLMs! Welcome to use!

The theme for the day (and probably at least the rest of the week) will be attention. the process for the next few days is going to be pretty straight forward, we start one bit at a time, write a ton of tests against known good reference implementations and move slowly. For this stack our reference implementations will be Llama3.1 and DSV2, which means one vanilla GQA llama attention block and one MLA block. We also need to implement a 1:6 global / local block from this blog post
research.character.ai/optimizing-inf‚Ä¶
using a modified LongFormer
arxiv.org/abs/2004.05150‚Ä¶
and the StreamingLLM attention block for our speculative decoding system
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

As some of those don't have working reference implementations, we will instead be comparing them to the output of our vanilla attention system as the established baseline. This whole process is a bit of a pain at first but if you take your time and get it right, it allows you to run experiments very quickly and with a lot of confidence vs just looking at the output of the models and hoping you didn't screw something up too badly.
Exciting news! üöÄ Our H2O fast LLM inference just got even better! It outperforms StreamingLLM (
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

) in multiple benchmarks and now also offers long generation (up to 4M tokens), as StreamingLLM.  

We will present H2O next Tuesday (Poster session 1, 10:45-12:45 local time) in NeurIPS'23. Welcome to attend!

I have tested this AI tool on a continuous stream of information that I get 24/7 from a 7000+ RSS feed of news and insight.

Every 7 minutes I get a synopsis update of what is going on in the world.

I will show you how FOR FREE.

At
ReadMultiplex.com
soon.

Boom!

A new technique named "StreamingLLM" can handle infinite text input without any drop in accuracy by using key tokens that guide the model's decisions and caching recent tokens.

The result: 22x faster inference.
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

legacy.name: Lior‚ö°

entities.text: Welcome to StreamingLLM, enabling non-stop conversation. We discover the attention sink phenomenon (the first few tokens in the KV cache are important). The secret sauce is to preserve the attention sink.  Note: this is not infinite context.
A quick visual summary from

entities.name: nerdai
entities.text: @_nerdai_
on the paper we were looking at last week about using "attention sinks" to improve the performance of LLMs over long context windows:
x.com/_nerdai_/statu‚Ä¶

A toy visualization of how the "infinite KV cache" in MLX LM works.

Some notes:
- You always keep the first n tokens (n=1 in this toy example and n=4 in MLX LM)
- The maximum cache size is 4 in this toy example (specify it with `--max-kv-size` in MLX LM)
- If you follow the arrows from t=1 to t=7, you see that the last token still depends causally on all the initial tokens. But the dependence is mediated through other tokens instead of direct. That's why there is some accuracy loss.
- It uses a circular buffer which is really nice because it's super efficient. You don't have to copy the whole cache, just overwrite one spot. The invariance of self-attention to the order of inputs is a feature here.

Reference:
browse.arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

Here's a list of my favorite LLM papers I read this month:

1/ Zephyr LLM - a 7B parameter model with competitive performance to ChatGPT on AlpacaEval; applies distilled supervised fine-tuning to improve task accuracy and distilled direct performance optimization on AI feedback data to better align the model; shows performance comparable to 70B-parameter chat models aligned with human feedback.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.16944
2/ LLMs Meet New Knowledge - presents a benchmark to assess LLMs' abilities in knowledge understanding, differentiation, and association; benchmark results show
arxiv.org/abs/2310.14820

3/ Llemma - an LLM for mathematics which is based on continued pretraining from Code Llama on the Proof-Pile-2 dataset; the dataset involves scientific paper, web data containing mathematics, and mathematical code; Llemma outperforms open base models and the unreleased Minerva on the MATH benchmark; the model is released, including dataset and code to replicate experiments.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.10631
4/ LLMs for Software Engineering - a comprehensive survey of LLMs for software engineering, including open research and technical challenges.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.03533

5/ Self-RAG - presents a new retrieval-augmented framework that enhances an LM‚Äôs quality and factuality through retrieval and self-reflection; trains an LM that adaptively retrieves passages on demand, and generates and reflects on the passages and its own generations using special reflection tokens; it significantly outperforms SoTA LLMs.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.11511
6/ Instruct-Retro - introduces Retro 48B, the largest LLM pretrained with retrieval; continues pretraining a 43B parameter GPT model on an additional 100B tokens by retrieving from 1.2T tokens.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.07713
7/ Overview of Factuality in LLMs - a survey of factuality in LLMs providing insights into how to evaluate factuality in LLMs and how to enhance it.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.07521

8/ LLMs Represent Space and Time - discovers that LLMs learn linear representations of space and time across multiple scales; the representations are robust to prompt variations and unified across different entity types; demonstrate that LLMs acquire fundamental structured knowledge such as space and time, claiming that language models learn beyond superficial statistics, but literal world models.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.02207

9/ StreamingLLM - a framework that enables efficient streaming LLMs with attention sinks, a phenomenon where the KV states of initial tokens will largely recover the performance of window attention; the emergence of the attention sink is due to strong attention scores towards the initial tokens; this approach enables LLMs trained with finite length attention windows to generalize to infinite sequence length without any additional fine-tuning.
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

10/ Retrieval meets Long Context LLMs - compares retrieval augmentation and long-context windows for downstream tasks to investigate if the methods can be combined to get the best of both worlds; an LLM with a 4K context window using simple RAG can achieve comparable performance to a fine-tuned LLM with 16K context; retrieval can significantly improve the performance of LLMs regardless of their extended context window sizes; a retrieval-augmented LLaMA2-70B with a 32K context window outperforms GPT-3.5-turbo-16k on seven long context tasks including question answering and query-based summarization.
arxiv.org/abs/2310.03025
You can find more interesting papers for this and past months here:
github.com/dair-ai/ML-Pap‚Ä¶
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

"Efficient Streaming Language Models with Attention Sinks"

TLDR: An efficient method to perform inference over longer sequences based on the observation that the first token in a sequence plays an essential role in attention.

Details in thread  üëá

This is the future of LLMs. 

A new technique named "StreamingLLM" can handle infinite text input without any drop in accuracy.

It works finding key tokens that guide the model's decisions and caching recent tokens.

The result: It delivers up to 22x faster inference than vanilla LLMs.

Paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
Code:
github.com/mit-han-lab/st‚Ä¶
MIT & Meta break new ground in generative AI! Introducing
#StreamingLLM

, addressing challenges of LLMs in streaming apps. They‚Äôve unveiled a method for infinite sequence lengths, achieving up to 22.2x speedup over existing methods! A game-changer for dialogue-driven applications.
#AIInnovation
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

üìö Imagine an AI with a photographic memory of your conversations and lightning-fast text processing. With up to 22x faster inference, it preserves context effortlessly. No more forgotten chats or text limitations. StreamingLLM redefines language models! üí¨‚ú®

arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

) phenomenon for streaming ASR which leads to improved WER during challenging streaming settings with limited left context!

[7/n]

Meet StreamingLLM! Use LLMs for infinite input streams without losing efficiency and performance.

Now, you can build a ChatBot that persistently works on your recent chats!

This "attention sink" trick does allow your LLM work on an unbounded length of input without any degradation in perplexity - but of course that doesn't mean it's really using its full context.

This line from p2 made sense to me: "[sinks] collect significant attention. We attribute . to . Softmax ., which requires . scores . sum . to 1 . even if .  query does not have a strong match in . previous tokens, .still . allocate .  attention values somewhere".

reminds me of this post--i wonder if there would be value in giving LLMs a separate [reg] token, pinned to the start of the sequence, to decouple it from any semantics of the start-of-sequence token
x.com/TimDarcet/stat‚Ä¶

Yeah agreed. For toy LLMs I've been using a BOS token that's distinct from the <|endoftext|> separator. I think the "right" approach is probably a pinned register token like you said, plus inter-sequence masking (though that would require Flash Attention support)
I figure this is somewhat similar to the paper on registers for ViT in carrying global information, but being able to carry it forward across windows?

Sort of but sort of not. They're similar to ViT registers in that they allow for attending away from content, but because it's still all causally masked, there's no (iterative) global message passing like there is in ViT.

Exactly. The point is to accelerate LLMs without retraining them.

So the intuition is you keep the first and last KV pairs because the middle will "muddy" the water knowing the matrix identities have to equal 1 so it gives the attention to the initial query and latest info on it. However what I wonder is how to detect the start of a new conversation "session", say you are in a thread like in chatgpt, how can you detect the start of a new topic so you can apply this strategy to grow the inference indefinitely within that session? Because otherwise people change topics frequently and the latest info will be very different than the initial query which likely will give weird results
Funny how I was just talking about with ithers and querying  chat gpt on live indexing. ü§£

‚Ä¶ can efficiently model text up to 4 million tokens. üëÄ

Here‚Äôs a summary of the research paper: Efficient Streaming Language Models with Attention Sinks

Full article:
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453
some amazing possibilities in that, who will deliver it first to the open source market?
Well hello there stream of digital consciousness!
There are a few ways attention is extended over longer sequences:
1. In dense attention, we simply extend the sequence length past what the model was trained on. This has both bad performance at long-range modeling and bad efficiency as our KV cache blows up.
2. In windowed attention we only cache and compute attention over the previous L tokens. While this method is efficient, performance drops substantially.

3. In sliding window attention, we only perform attention over the previous L tokens, but no longer maintain a KV-cache and instead re-compute attention over all L tokens. While this method has good performance, it's less efficient due to the recomputation.

In determining why windowed attention fails, the researchers find what they call ‚Äúattention sinks‚Äù. Models reliably assign high attention scores to the first few tokens in the sequence. 

(This observation that some tokens are ‚Äúattention sinks‚Äù has been noted before (registers))
So when we perform windowed attention, and our current position does not include the first tokens, performance decreases even if the first token isn‚Äôt semantically relevant.
Now onto the fix: ‚ÄúStreaming LLMs‚Äù. The idea is to perform windowed attention but keep the first few tokens in our KV-cache so that tokens later in the sequence can still use them as sinks.
Performance results: StreamingLLMs outperform both dense attention and windowed attention at long sequences and have commensurate performance for sliding window attention!
Efficiency results: To compare speed improvements, they compare Streaming LLM with sliding window w/ re-computation. They find that at seq len 4096, streaming achieves a 22x speedup!

Sink-aware pre-training: What if instead of just changing how we do decoding at inference time, we incorporated the notion of sinks during pre-training? The authors propose to prepend each sequence with a special Sink token, that effectively acts as a no-op.
Having a Sink token results in both better downstream performance and more regular attention maps for actual tokens!
Conclusion: I thought this was an amazing paper that both demonstrated an interesting observation about attention and used it to make a really powerful inference solution.
I‚Äôm not the most informed about inference, but dense attention for long sequences seems problematic given both poor length generalization of models and the blow-up of the KV-cache.

Not only does this method perform better at long-range modeling, it is also more efficient. As a bonus, Sink token pre-training seems to help standard short model eval and produces more regular attention maps, which might enable better model quantization.

Also thanks to the ML Sys reading group at MIT for the discussion on the paper!
Huge thanks to the authors (

et al) for an awesome read!

You could try to do a Sliding Window Block Attention, for example, keep some sinks, 64 window size, when the window is full copy the last 32 tokens to the beginning and mask the last 32. That way you always keep a longer context and only have to copy once every 32 tokens

I hope I understand it correctly. It seems that the initial tokens are attention sink, and a sliding window is applied to the tokens in cache? I'm still reading the paper, but I found the implementation in mlx_lm much easier to understand.ü´°
So we always keeping the first initial token (n=1), this is attention sink, right?

Previously, using LLMs for endless chats was hard. 

1. Caching all past tokens' KV consumes too much memory. 
2. When chat length exceeds the pre-training length, performance plunges. 

Window attention only saves recent tokens' KV, which fails as initial tokens' KV are evicted.

We find an "attention sink" phenomenon: retaining the KV of initial tokens can restore window attention performance.   Interestingly, these tokens have strong attention scores, acting as a "sink," even if they lack semantic importance.

Based on attention sinks, we propose StreamingLLM, an efficient framework that enables LLMs to accept super-long input streams without fine-tuning. StreamingLLM enables Llama-2, MPT, Falcon, and Pythia to perform stable and efficient language modeling with up to 4M tokens!

In StreamingLLM, we believe the rise of attention sinks links to the SoftMax function. It demands attention scores sum to one, even if there's no strong match in prior tokens. Thus, models "dump" excess attention into attention sinks.
Attention sinks echos with

entities.name: Evan Miller
entities.text: @EvMill
's "SoftMax-off-by-One" and the paper "ViTs need registers". We all highlight potential SoftMax issues in Attention.

Hi! Quick question: in Table 2 you show that Llama-2-7B requires quite a few initial tokens to restore performance to baseline. Was that the non-RLHFd model? Have you tried the benchmark with Llama2-7B-chat? Its input format already essentially has a fixed BOS token, so I'm curious if just keeping one initial token would be enough for it.
We will look into that soon, but I guess the chat model may still need several initial tokens to recover the performance. üòÑ

arxiv.org/abs/2201.03533

üö® üîî Paper alert in Efficient Streaming ASR üîîüö®

I'm super excited to release our paper ‚ÄúXLSR-Transducer: Streaming ASR for Self-Supervised Pretrained Models‚Äù

abs:
arxiv.org/abs/2407.04439

This work was part of our efforts on bringing streaming ASR solutions for low-resource scenarios. We did this by replacing the encoder in Transducer models with a pre-trained XLSR model.

This has been done before, but we took it to the next level by...

[2/n]

1) trying it on open-source models and datasets, 
2) exploring the attention sinks phenomenon for streaming ASR, 
and 3) extensive evaluation on different training and test settings. Including non-streaming and streaming.

Now, a short thread about the main findings! üß∂

[3/n]

Current SOTA Transducers ASR are trained from scratch. We replace the encoder w/ XLSR-53, ie, suitable for low-resource applications. Our contributions lead to the XLSR-Transducer.

[4/n]

Our main contributions:

1) Introduce XLSR-Transducer, a multilingual SSL encoder based transducer model, demonstrating significant WER improvement on the AMI and CommonVoice w.r.t large speech foundational models.

[5/n]

2) extension to streaming XLSR-Transducer + a systematic study of chunk size and left context on training and inference.

[6/n]

Masking patterns to enable streaming decoding

Masking strategies for streaming XLSR-Transducer. Multi-chunk training allows decoding with variable chunk size (blue) and left context (orange). Each square denotes ‚Äún‚Äù frames. 

[8/n]

Attention sink (yellow) allows context from the first n frames. Our results show that attention sink frames offer a better trade-off w.r.t increasing left context alone, ie lower WERs.

[9/n]

Some WERs on AMI dataset!

On streaming decoding, the multi-chunk training (multiple) provides significant gain w.r.t encoders trained from scratch with minimal degradation in non-streaming performance.

[10/n]

Attention sink for Efficient streaming ASR!

Now, the juicy part of the paper! The Attention sink results: WERs on AMI eval set for varied decoding settings. Adding attention sinks offer a better trade off than increasing left context. 

[11/n]

In blue, we show relative WER reduction w.r.t no attention sink within the same chunk and left context.

[12/n]

and ü•Åü™ò that's all! Thank you for reading!
paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2407.04439

This work was led by a super smart colleague: Shashi Kumar.

w/ Srikanth Madikeri, me, Esau Villa,  Yulia Nigmatulina, Petr Motlicek, Manjunath K , Aravind Ganapathiraju!

authors find a surprisingly large amount of attention score is allocated to the initial tokens, irrespective of their relevance to the language modeling task. They term these tokens ‚Äúattention sinks".

Based on this insight, they preserve "attention sinks" with high attention values, alongside a sliding window of recent tokens. This approach enables models like Llama-2, MPT, Falcon, and Pythia to process significantly long texts (up to 4 million tokens) more efficiently.

Our H2O approach now can handle infinite stream of input and is better than StreamingLLM!

Check out our NeurIPS 2023 work: H2O: Heavy-Hitter Oracle (
arxiv.org/abs/2306.14048
), to empower LLMs for efficient and effective generation inference.

Don't miss this interesting demo and welcome to discuss with us next week (12 Dec 10:45 a.m. CST at Great Hall & Hall B1+B2 #534)

Blog:
allenz.work/?p=11
Code:
github.com/FMInference/H2O

Deploying LLMs faces two major hurdles: (i) High costs of KV Cache (ii) Poor Generation to long (-> infinite) sequences.

To address this limitation, we proposed Heavy-Hitter Oracle, that kills two ‚Äúbirds‚Äù (High costs and poor generation) with one ‚Äústone‚Äù (‚Äúheavy-hitters‚Äù).

The key insight of H2O is from the observation that a small subset of tokens play a critical role in the whole generation stage (with a significant large accumulated attention scores). We visualize the its distribution during generation and observe a power-law distribution.

Notably, some recent advancements(StreamingLLM and LM-Infinite) have empowered LLMs to handle infinite‚Äù-length sequences by: (1) storing the first few tokens as attention sink, and (2) applying position rolling in the KV cache.

However, in some tasks, the important information might exist in the region that will be ignored by such token dropping policy(e.g., multi-document question answering).

Is there a better way to dynamically maintain important information instead of the first few tokens?
Motivated by this, We combine position rolling with H2O and observe a better long-context understanding ability of LLMs, as well as streaming LLM to infinite length in the meantime.

By dynamically filtering out unnecessary tokens, H2O enables efficient and effective LLM generation: (1) Achieving 3x-29x, 29x, 3x throughput improvement than other leading inference systems. (2) Handling long (-> infinite) sequences inputs. Find more in
allenz.work/?p=11

Hi, Allen. 
 
Do you have a plan to combine sparse prediction, heavy hitter and flexgen togatherÔºü
Hi, Allen. Thanks for your work which reduces the KV cache.  Is H2O compatible with paged attention or is it easy to integrate H2O into existing inference frameworks ?

Hi, Shuai. From my understanding, H2O (removing unnecessary KVs) is orthogonal to paged attention that dynamically allocate memory for kv cache. Thus they should be compatible. Currently, our method is build on the top of Flexgen system and we plan to integrate it on more.

"Can we deploy an LLM for infinite-length inputs without sacrificing efficiency and performance?"

This is the question considered by the authors of the paper, entitled

"Efficient Streaming Language Models With Attention Sinks" (
arxiv.org/pdf/2309.17453‚Ä¶

It's an important question and answering it in the affirmative is necessary to unlock a multitude of important and practical applications such as those involving multi-round dialogue. Where last week's PaperCard on LongLoRA also studied how to make LLMs work with ... 

(2/5)

long-context inputs, this paper ups the ante by considering infinite-length input without any fine-tuning!

The authors of discovered that attention is disproportionately allocated to initial tokens irrespective of semantics, calling them attention sinks.

The idea then ...
(3/5)

to retain only these attention sink tokens along with a sliding window of recent tokens when decoding. Doing so drastically reduces the memory requirements as compared to dense attn, yet doesn't suffer from performance degradation like vanilla Sliding Window Attn does

(4/5)

Et voila ! With this simple framework, it is possible to deploy LLMs that work with infinite-length inputs. If that's not worthy of a Golden status, then I don't know what is!

(More of these PaperCards can be found in my personal webpage linked here:¬†
nerdai.io/cards

Introducing StreamingLLM.

Imagine chatting with an AI assistant that can contextually reference your conversations from weeks or months ago. Or summarizing reports that span thousands of pages. StreamingLLM makes this possible by enabling language models to smoothly handle endless texts without losing steam. 

Current LLMs are like students cramming for an exam - they can only memorize a limited context. StreamingLLM is the valedictorian with a photographic memory of everything you've ever discussed. 

It works by identifying and preserving the model's inherent "attention sinks" - initial tokens that anchored its reasoning. Combined with a rolling cache of recent tokens, StreamingLLM delivers up to 22x faster inference without any drop in accuracy.

You know that irksome feeling when chatbots forget your earlier conversations? StreamingLLM abolishes that frustration. It remembers the touchdowns from your last game and your newborn's name without missing a beat. 

Monumental books, verbose contracts, drawn out debates - StreamingLLM takes them all in its stride. No shortcuts, no forgetfulness. It's like upgrading your assistant's RAM to handle heavier workloads flawlessly.

Key advantages of StreamingLLM over other approaches are:

- Enables infinite length streaming without needing to increase model capacity or fine-tune the model. Methods like expanding the attention window require substantially more compute for training larger models.

- Much more efficient than alternatives like sliding window with recomputation. StreamingLLM provides up to 22x speedup per token decoding.

- Stable performance on texts massively longer than training length. Matches performance of sliding window baseline on 4 million+ tokens.

- Simple and versatile. Easily incorporated into models with relative position encoding like RoPE or ALiBi.

- Pre-training with sink token further boosts streaming capability with just a single token.

- Decouples model pre-training length from actual generation length. Allows extending model use cases.

So in summary, StreamingLLM unlocks efficient and performant infinite-length streaming from pretrained LLMs without modulation, and is superior to other techniques on metrics like speed, compute overhead and length generalizability.

Here's the StreamingLLM method:

Background:
- Autoregressive language models are limited to contexts of finite length due to the quadratic self-attention complexity.
- Windowed attention partially addresses this by caching only the most recent tokens.
- However, window attention fails once initial tokens are removed from the cache. 

Key Idea:
- Initial tokens act as "attention sinks", collecting scores irrespective of meaning due to the softmax normalization. 
- Preserve these tokens alongside a rolling cache to stabilize attention distributions.

Approach:
- Split KV cache into two segments:
   - Attention Sinks: Consists of the first 4 tokens of the sequence. 
   - Rolling Cache: Holds the most recent T tokens.
- For each new decoded token:
   - Evict the oldest token from the rolling cache.
   - Append the new token to the rolling cache.
   - Compute self-attention over [Attention Sinks + Rolling Cache].
- Apply relative position encoding within the cache rather than full sequence.
Okay enough elevator talk, where's the damn paper?
arxiv.org/abs/2309.17453

"Is the context window of LLMs expanded?

No. The context window remains unchanged. Only the most recent tokens and attention sinks are retained, discarding middle tokens. This means the model can only process the latest tokens. The context window remains constrained by its initial pre-training. For instance, if Llama-2 is pre-trained with a context window of 4096 tokens, then the maximum cache size for StreamingLLM on Llama-2 remains 4096"

You misunderstood this llm

A quote from the README:

‚ÄûCan I input an extensive text, like a book, into StreamingLLM for summarization?
While you can input a lengthy text, the model will only recognize the latest tokens. Thus, if a book is an input, StreamingLLM might only summarize the concluding paragraphs, which might not be very insightful. As emphasized earlier, we neither expand the LLMs' context window nor enhance their long-term memory. StreamingLLM's strength lies in generating fluent text from recent tokens without needing a cache refresh.‚Äù

Yeah. As soon as it takes a wrong turn you eventually end up so far off you're into Q or something. 

A better world, indeed.

the window size is like how much prompt it can look at. for each word generated, you need to compute something for each previous word, that you can reuse for the following words. reusing costs memory so it prevents you from doing longer sequences

the previous approach is to just discard the earlier parts of long sequences, or hold on to all of that information. iiuc, this is something in between, you discard most of the information about previous words, but put some of that information on a special fake word at the start
as an optimization, this mostly gets you speedups for long sequences that don't fit in the default window size, and doesn't get you speedups for short prompts / outputs
